title: Slipping
subtitle: Slip punches — stay in range while making your opponent miss.

steps.text: In stance. Eyes forward over knuckles, chin down, rear heel off the floor.
To slip rear-side, bring lead hand up slightly and turn your upper body toward your rear foot. Roll with the punch.
Side view: body turns away from the punch using hips. Lead hand defends.
To slip lead-side, twist upper body toward lead foot, bringing rear hand up to shield. Chin tucked.
Side view: pivot on the rear foot ball to increase rotation.

takeaways: Slipping helps you avoid punches without leaving range — perfect for countering.
Slip rear-side by turning your upper body toward your rear foot, lead hand up to shield.
Slip lead-side by turning toward your lead foot, rear hand up to shield your chin.

title: Rolling
subtitle: Roll under hooks to the head — stay close, stay safe, stay dangerous.

steps.text: Assuming orthodox stance and opponent throws a hook from your right, slip lead-side and shift weight to lead foot.
Drop your weight onto your lead leg, about one head-height. Like a shallow lunge.
Turn your body and shift weight to rear leg while low. Eyes forward. Chin tucked.
Still squatting, weight now over rear leg. Lead hand shields face.
Raise your body to return to stance. For opposite direction, mirror the sequence.

takeaways: Start by slipping toward your lead side and dropping low to avoid the hook.
Draw a U-shape under the punch by shifting weight from lead to rear leg while staying low.
Keep your guard up, eyes forward, and finish back in your stance — ready to respond.

title: Blocking & Parrying
subtitle: Block and parry — simple defenses to stay safe at all ranges.

steps.text: Block straight shots by extending your lead arm bent to meet the punch with your forearm. Best used at long range.
Front view of blocking with lead forearm. Keep chin tucked.
Catch straight shots with rear hand turned out. Most effective at long range.
Front view of rear hand parry.
Block rear-side hook to the body by bringing rear fist up about 2 inches from chin. Thumb near earlobe. Elbow tucked.
Block lead-side hook to the head by bringing lead hand up with elbow locked.
To block body hooks, hinge at the hips while keeping the same arm position.
Alternate side of body hook block using same hip-hinge technique.
Shelling up can be used temporarily, but use footwork to escape and avoid staying on the ropes.

takeaways: Lead forearm and rear hand parry are effective against straight shots — but only at long range.
Keep elbows tucked, hands up, and a slight gap from your face when blocking hooks.
Use hip hinge and proper arm positioning for body shots, and don’t stay shelled up — use footwork to escape.
